134dbf2d397958c2662405a8c5773b4e (11:16): if I have a current datetime field, and I want to check a couple hours later if the current time is in between the time and 24 hour interval, how can that query be done
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (11:29): Pi: Check your slow query log
dfed5bc177b87ab317c584e06566adc6 (11:29): you crazy kids and your logs
3af68829d2c367760c8b493619731afe (11:30): i have this problem: http://hashmysql.org/paste/viewentry.php?id=2595 can you help me?Thanks
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:32): Pi: You could also do a SHOW PROCESSLIST to see what may be still executing that is taking up the resources.
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:33): mike-ekim-: SELECT * FROM table WHERE now() between date and DATEADD(date, INTERVAL 24 HOUR)

2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:34): mike-ekim-: Note that query is not optimal with the now() function in there. You could escape that with a user variable if you need large amounts of data processed.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (11:34): Alternatively, SELECT foo FROM bar WHERE DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 24 HOUR) <= datetime_col;
69aa6b797f62c288f488c1978743ac0d (11:37): hi.       is        tabl.column = tabl2.column           the same as  USING('column')      when doing JOINs
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:37): romaluca: Because your WHERE condition takes out all dates before the date you set.
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:38): jmut: The USING clause is much better for the MySQL optimiser than doing the comparison in the WHERE clause.
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:39): romaluca: There is no problem with the query, just the date takes out the one  you want.
69aa6b797f62c288f488c1978743ac0d (11:39): Jonathon: but can it produce different output    or is it just better practice to use USING

2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:40): jmut: The optimiser can be greatly influenced depending on which one you use. So if you use the condition in WHERE, it may cause a more inefficient path of execution for MySQL.
69aa6b797f62c288f488c1978743ac0d (11:41): Jonathon: :) ok. so I assume as result set returned it matters not. as speed it is better to use USING... Thank you
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:42): romaluca: Oops.. sorry, I misread your date as 21st, rather than 20th. Checking again.
2987999ecd797c35a1339b546a4f96bb (11:45): romaluca: OK. It is because 31 is the first record in the group that is above the date you specified.
